author: gcolvin

> Fun fact: Alternatives considered and Objections are not sections in the EIP template!

From EIP-1:
> Rationale - The rationale fleshes out the specification by describing what motivated the design and why particular design decisions were made. It should describe alternate designs that were considered and related work, e.g. how the feature is supported in other languages. The rationale should discuss important objections or concerns raised during discussion around the EIP.

author: gcolvin
content:
> The split is the refactor step, then we will go bonkers with the proces changes.  Aligning them tightly with the draft/EFI/CFI/Testnet/Mainnet lifecycle.

This is probably at the heart of my concerns -- what I'd like is actually to simplify the normal editing lifecycle for Core proposals to Draft -> Final.  The Draft is open to change throughout the editing process, and the Final document corresponds to what goes on the mainnet.   The Core process (currently EFI/CFI/Testnet/Mainnet) is not the Editors concern.

Following the IETF, I'd also want to give working groups a lot more say in the form of their proposals -- what sections are required etc.  The Editors maintain basic "style sheet" standards of spelling, citation format, etc.

author: gcolvin
content:
Given control of form of the documents, it should be much easier for the protocol developers to adapt the process to meet their needs.

And having simplified the process (back to where it started) and separated the editorial and core development concerns its remains unclear to me that a separate EIP repo is needed (though Github might tie our hands.). Where an EIP is in the Core workflow should (IMHO) be tracked in the ethereum/pm repo, not the EIP repo.  But again, I'll need to study your document.
